post.titolo: The consecration of the dagger to Apollo at Delphi
post.descrizione: From the foundation of Padua the theme of the frescoes shifts to that of the journey made by the hero. From the foundation of Padua the theme of the frescoes shifts to that of the journey made by the hero. The central character in the composition is Helicaone, the son of Antenor, kneeling in front of the sculpture of Apollo intent on handing the dagger to the God. To the right of Helicaone stands out a haruspex with his head adorned with an olive crown. Antenor is portrayed from the back, engaged in a discussion with a graduate, as can be deduced from the clothing and headgear. In the upper part there is Minerva pacificata who holds an olive branch in her hands. The uniqueness of the fresco is given by the presence of clear references to antiquity. However, the elements are adopted with the simple purpose of complementing the setting and are not linked to the classic antiquated objects often found in the homes of Paduan collectors. Furthermore, the absence of inspiration from the classical model, which can be guessed in the sculpture of Apollo and in its base, is evident.
